thread.title: NASA reveals what happens to an astronaut's body during a year in space
thread.title_full: NASA reveals what happens to an astronaut's body during a year in space - Mirror Online

author: Mark Leatham
title: NASA reveals what happens to an astronaut's body during a year in space
text:
Ever wondered what happens to an astronaut's body in outer space?
Wonder no more, because a NASA chart shows what NASA astronaut Scott Kelly's body is going through as he spends 12 months on the International Space Station.
Scott is around halfway through a year in space .
READ MORE: Will a meteor wipe out life on Earth? Scientists are examining one that already did NASA Space Odyssey: It's a physical and mental challenge
He will exercise more than 700 hours during his year-long mission as he strives to keep his bones, muscles and heart strong. That's two hours a day on average.
For hydration he will drink 730 litres of recycled urine and sweat whilst keeping fit by running 648 miles on a specialised treadmill.
The astronaut will also produce about 180 pounds of faeces which will burn up in the atmosphere looking like shooting stars.
Day 173. Cruising the #sunset strip tonight. Good night from @space_station ! #YearInSpace pic.twitter.com/c1KzLSqs2O
— Scott Kelly (@StationCDRKelly) September 16, 2015 Today I began the 2nd half of my #YearInSpace ! Having circled the globe 2,736 times, here's one full orbit for you!
 https://t.co/TZiqIFu7Xa
— Scott Kelly (@StationCDRKelly) September 16, 2015
For anyone thinking he's got the best job in the world, it's worth noting that it takes an incredible amount of hard work, endurance and skill.
Around 383 experiments will be conducted during his time in outer space, including some created by Nobel Laureates.
Scott said on NASA's website: “I think the legacy of this mission will be based on the science of having us in space for a year.
"The great data we collected, what we learned about being in space for this long and how that will help our journey to Mars someday.”
Scott has over 430,000 followers on Twitter where he documents daily life on the International Space Station, regularly posting incredible space pictures and videos.
